Article.Abstract: Ag85B (also known as alpha antigen or MPT59) is immunogenic, and induces expansion and differentiation of TCRVbeta11(+)CD4(+) T cells to IFN-gamma-producing cells in C57BL/6 (I-A(b)) mice. We reported that Peptide-25 (amino acids 240-254) of Ag85B is a major T cell epitope, and its amino acid residues at position 244, 247, 249 and 252 are I-A(b) contact residues. Here we examined roles of IFN-gamma in the generation of Peptide-25-reactive CD4(+) TCRVbeta11(+) T cells and the efficacy of mutant peptides of Peptide-25 for T(h)1 development in mice other than C57BL/6 mice. Immunization of C57BL/6 mice with Peptide-25 included in incomplete Freund's adjuvant led to preferential induction of CD4(+) TCRVbeta11(+) IFN-gamma- and tumor necrosis factor-alpha-producing T cells. Compared with other I-A(b)-binding peptides such as Peptide-9 of Ag85B, 50V of pigeon cytochrome c and ovalbumin (OVA)(265-280) peptide, only Peptide-25 was capable of inducing enormous expansion of TCRVbeta11(+) IFN-gamma-producing T cells. Treatment of C57BL/6 mice with anti-Vbeta11 antibody before Peptide-25 immunization reduced the development of CD4(+) IFN-gamma-producing T cells. Furthermore, B10.A(3R) mice, I-A(b)-positive and TCRVbeta11(-) strain, showed remarkably lower response to Peptide-25 immunization than C57BL/6 mice. Peptide-25-primed IFN-gamma(-/-) cells showed significantly decreased expansion of CD4(+) TCRVbeta11(+) T cells as compared with wild-type cells. Interestingly, Peptide-25-primed cells from MyD88-deficient mice responded to Peptide-25 and differentiated into IFN-gamma-producing cells to a similar extent as wild-type mice, indicating Toll-like receptor-independent IFN-gamma production. These results imply that IFN-gamma plays important roles for the generation and expansion of CD4(+) TCRVbeta11(+) T cells in response to Peptide-25. Although Peptide-25 was non-immunogenic in C3H/HeN mice, a substituted mutant of Peptide-25, 244D247V, capable of binding to I-A(k), induced T(h)1 development. These results clearly demonstrate important roles of IFN-gamma in the expansion of CD4(+) TCRVbeta11(+) T cells, and will provide useful information for delineating the regulatory mechanisms of T(h)1-cell development and for analyzing mechanisms on T(h)1-dominant immune responses.
Article.ArticleTitle: Immunogenicity of Peptide-25 of Ag85B in Th1 development: role of IFN-gamma.
Article.Affiliations: Division of Immunology, Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Center for Experimental Medicine, Institute of Medical Science, University of Tokyo, 4-6-1 Shirokanedai, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108-8639, Japan.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Antigens, Bacterial(chemistry; immunology); CD4-Positive T-Lymphocytes(immunology); Cell Differentiation; Cytokines(biosynthesis); Genes, T-Cell Receptor alpha; Interferon-gamma(biosynthesis; physiology); Mice; Molecular Sequence Data; Mycobacterium tuberculosis(immunology); Peptides(chemistry; immunology); Point Mutation; T-Lymphocytes(immunology; metabolism); Th1 Cells(immunology); Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha(biosynthesis)

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The purpose of this assay was to examine the role of TCRVβ11+ T cells in the development of IFN-γ-producing T cells. Intracellular cytokine production by CD4+ cells was high in C57BL/6 mice and marginal in B10.A(3R) mice. IFN-γ and TCRVβ11+ cells were significantly reduced in peptide-25-primed, IFN-γ deficient mice, while they were similar to wild-type mice in MyD88-deficient mice. MyD88 is an adaptor molecule essential for signaling via the Toll-like receptor (TLR)/IL-1 receptor family.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The purpose of this assay was to examine the role of TCRVβ11+ T cells in the development of IFN-γ-producing T cells. While B10.A(3R) (TCRVβ11-) mice showed positive proliferative responses to the peptide, a subsequent analysis of intracellular cytokine levels of CD4+ cells from both strains revealed high levels in C57BL/6 mice, and marginal levels in B10.A(3R) mice.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The purpose of this assay was to examine the role of TCRVβ11+ T cells in the development of IFN-γ-producing T cells. While B10.A(3R) (TCRVβ11-) mice also showed positive proliferative responses to the peptide, a subsequent analysis of intracellular cytokine levels of CD4+ cells from both strains revealed high levels in C57BL/6 mice, and marginal levels in B10.A(3R) mice. Proliferation and IFN-γ production by peptide-25-primed cells from anti-Vβ11 antibody-treated C57BL/6 mice was ~50% less than these of the control group.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The purpose of this assay was to examine the role of TCRVβ11+ T cells in the development of IFN-γ-producing T cells. Intracellular cytokine production by CD4+ cells was high in C57BL/6 mice and marginal in B10.A(3R) mice. Proliferation and IFN-γ production by peptide-25-primed cells from anti-Vβ11 antibody-treated C57BL/6 mice was ~50% less than in the control group. Levels of IFN-γ and TCRVβ11+ cells were significantly reduced in peptide-25-primed, IFN-γ deficient mice, while they were similar to wild-type mice in MyD88-deficient mice. MyD88 is an adaptor molecule essential for signaling via the Toll-like receptor (TLR)/IL-1 receptor family.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Large proportions of peptide-25-reactive IFN-γ-producing cells were TCRVβ11+ T cells. To compare the immunogenicity of peptide-25 with other I-Ab binding peptides regarding the development of TCRVβ11+ IFN-γ-producing cells, peptide-9 of antigen 85B (DWSPACGKAGCQTY), 50V of pigeon cytochrome c (AEGFSYTVANKNKGIT), or OVA265-280 (TEWTSSNVMEERKIKV) were also assayed. While all peptides gave positive results, peptide-25 showed the most potent ability to induce IFN-γ-producing cells. The peptide was not immunogenic in C3H/HeN mice.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is an analog of Peptide-25 (FQDAYNAAGGHNAVF) from Antigen-85B of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once, and boosted 7 days before the experiment.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A positive ELISA response was also shown for IFN-γ secretion.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized with peptide once.
